abstract.p: Barbara Zuber letter on Isaac Stern's giving music lesson to 43 New York City school superintendents (May 11 article) scores interim schools chancellor Harold O Levy for absenting himself from event

block.p: It was graceful and charming of Isaac Stern to agree to give a violin lesson to New York City school superintendents (news article, May 11). And it was equally charming on the part of the 43 superintendents to accept the teaching and go with the flow. When in your life, after all, do you get the chance to be introduced to the world of string music by one of the greatest violin virtuosos of our time?

It was graceful and charming of Isaac Stern to agree to give a violin lesson to New York City school superintendents (news article, May 11). And it was equally charming on the part of the 43 superintendents to accept the teaching and go with the flow. When in your life, after all, do you get the chance to be introduced to the world of string music by one of the greatest violin virtuosos of our time?

But the moment was tarnished by Harold O. Levy, the interim schools chancellor. First he persuaded Mr. Stern to come. But once Mr. Stern and the 43 superintendents got together in one room, Mr. Levy decided that he had more important things to do. He left and accompanied his son on a school field trip instead. At least those left behind seized the moment and chose high spirits and mutual appreciation instead of abandonment.
